posts.title: Java Streams Cookbook
posts.html:
[vc_row][vc_column][vc_column_text]

Introduction

todo

  • A brief history of streams API
  • Types of operations Aggregate/intermediate / terminal
[/vc_column_text][us_separator show_line=”1″ icon=”fas|code”][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_column][/vc_column][vc_row][vc_column][us_cta title=”Sample Code” color=”secondary” btn_label=”Code” btn_link=”url:https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fcodenerve-com%2Ftutorials%2Ftree%2Fmaster%2Fjava-cookbook||target:%20_blank|” btn_style=”2″ btn_size=”15px” btn_icon=”fab|github”]The code for this lesson is available on GitHub[/us_cta][us_separator show_line=”1″ icon=”fas|code”][vc_column_text]

Basic operations on Lists

[/vc_column_text][us_separator size=”small” show_line=”1″ icon=”fas|code”][vc_tta_tour switch_sections=”hover” layout=”trendy” title_font=””][vc_tta_section icon=”fas|sort” tab_id=”1593167147786-cbc0cd2f-dca3″ title=”Sort”][vc_column_text]

Input data

The following examples will use a list of book titles (strings):

(These have been taken at random from devconnected.com’s best Software Engineering Books in 2019)

    private final List<String> books = asList(
            "Clean Code",
            "Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software",
            "Patterns of Enterprise Application Architecture",
            "Enterprise Integration Patterns",
            "The Mythical Man-Month",
            "Code Complete",
            "Git for Teams",
            "Refactoring: Improving the Design of Existing Code",
            "The Art of Unit Testing",
            "Soft Skills: The Software Developer’s Life Manual");
[/vc_column_text][us_separator size=”small”][vc_column_text]

Sort strings in alphabetical order

Sorting a list of books in alphabetical order using sorted() i.e. natural ordering:

    @Test
    void sort_alphabetical() {
        List<Object> sortedList =
                books.stream()
                        .sorted()
                        .collect(toList());

        assertThat(sortedList.get(0), is(equalTo("Clean Code")));
        assertThat(sortedList.get(sortedList.size() -1), is(equalTo("The Mythical Man-Month")));
    }
[/vc_column_text][us_separator size=”small”][vc_column_text]

Sort strings in reverse alphabetical order

Sorting a list of books in reverse alphabetical order using sorted(Comparator.reverseOrder()):

    @Test
    void sort_reverse_alphabetical() {
        List<Object> sortedList =
                books.stream()
                        .sorted(Comparator.reverseOrder())
                        .collect(toList());

        assertThat(sortedList.get(0), is(equalTo("The Mythical Man-Month")));
        assertThat(sortedList.get(sortedList.size() -1), is(equalTo("Clean Code")));
    }
[/vc_column_text][us_separator size=”small”][vc_column_text]

Sort by string length

Sort the books in order of there title length using sorted(Comparator.comparing(String::length)):

    @Test
    void sort_by_title_length() {
        List<Object> sortedList =
                books.stream()
                        .sorted(Comparator.comparing(String::length))
                        .collect(toList());

        assertThat(sortedList.get(0), is(equalTo("Clean Code"))); // the shortest title
        assertThat(sortedList.get(sortedList.size() -1), is(equalTo("Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software"))); // the longest title
    }
[/vc_column_text][us_separator size=”small”][vc_column_text]

Sort string using a custom comparator

Sort the number of books by the number of times a letter ‘e’ occurs in there title:

    @Test
    void sort_by_custom_comparator() {
        List<Object> sortedList =
                books.stream()
                        .sorted(new CustomComparator())
                        .collect(toList());

        // the letter 3 occurs the most in this book.
        assertThat(sortedList.get(0), is(equalTo("Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software")));
    }

Where the custom comparator is:

import java.util.Comparator;

public class CustomComparator implements Comparator<String> {

    /*
        Sorts by the number of occurrences of the character 'e' in any given string
     */
    @Override
    public int compare(String string, String string2) {
        long stringCount = string.chars().filter(ch -> ch == 'e').count();
        long secondStringCount = string2.chars().filter(ch -> ch == 'e').count();
        return Long.compare(secondStringCount, stringCount);
    }
}
[/vc_column_text][/vc_tta_section][vc_tta_section icon=”fas|filter” tab_id=”1593167147801-27a547cc-163a” title=”Filter”][vc_column_text]

Input data

The following examples will use a list of book objects. Each book contains a title, an author and a rating out of 5:

N.B. these are all 5-star books but I have changed the ratings for the purpose of these examples.

    private final List<Book> books = asList(
            new Book("Clean Code", "Robert Martin", 5),
            new Book("Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software", "Eric Gamma", 4),
            new Book("Patterns of Enterprise Application Architecture", "Martin Fowler", 3),
            new Book("Enterprise Integration Patterns", "Gregor Hohpe", 5),
            new Book("The Mythical Man-Month", "Frederick Brooks", 4),
            new Book("Code Complete", "Steve McConnell", 3),
            new Book("Git for Teams", "Emma Hogbin Westby", 5),
            new Book("Refactoring: Improving the Design of Existing Code", "Martin Fowler", 4),
            new Book("The Art of Unit Testing", "Roy Osherove", 3),
            new Book("Soft Skills: The Software Developer’s Life Manual", "John Sonmez", 5));
[/vc_column_text][us_separator size=”small” show_line=”1″ icon=”fas|code”][vc_column_text]

Basic Filter

Filter Book objects based on there rating:

    @Test
    void filter_five_star_books() {

        List<Book> fiveStarBooks = books.stream()
                .filter(book -> book.getRating() == 5)
                .collect(Collectors.toList());

        assertThat(fiveStarBooks.size(), is(equalTo(4)));
    }
[/vc_column_text][us_separator size=”small” show_line=”1″ icon=”fas|code”][vc_column_text]

Multiple Filters

Since filter(…) is an intermediate operation you can call as many as you like. This example finds all five-star books with “Git” in their title:

    @Test
    void filter_five_star_git_books() {
        List<Book> fiveStarGitBooks = books.stream()
                .filter(book -> book.getRating() == 5)
                .filter(book -> book.getTitle().contains("Git"))
                .collect(Collectors.toList());

        assertThat(fiveStarGitBooks.size(), is(equalTo(1)));
    }
[/vc_column_text][us_separator size=”small” show_line=”1″ icon=”fas|code”][vc_column_text]

Expanding Lambda Body

More complicated predicate conditions can be created by expanding out the filters lambda body. This filters all boos with an even rating:

    @Test
    void filter_even_ratings() {
        List<Book> bookILike = books.stream()
                .filter(book -> {
                    return book.getRating() % 2 == 0;
                })
                .collect(Collectors.toList());

        assertThat(bookILike.size(), is(equalTo(3)));
    }
[/vc_column_text][us_separator size=”small” show_line=”1″ icon=”fas|code”][vc_column_text]

Filtering on predicates

Useful for code re-use you can declare Predicates elsewhere and use in your filters. This example finds all book titles with “Patterns” in the title:

    @Test
    void filter_pattern_books() {
        List<Book> fiveStarBooks = books.stream()
                .filter(patternBooks)
                .collect(Collectors.toList());

        assertThat(fiveStarBooks.size(), is(equalTo(3)));
    }

In this case the predicate is a field:

private final Predicate<Book> patternBooks = book -> book.getTitle().contains("Patterns");
[/vc_column_text][us_separator size=”small” show_line=”1″ icon=”fas|code”][vc_column_text]

findAny

Used to find any item in the collection that matches the filter(s) conditions. Returns an optional which could be empty (see optionals for more info). It is also important to note that this method is non-deterministic and can return different results if run multiple times.

This example finds any Robert Martin book:

    @Test
    void find_a_robert_martin_book() {
        Optional<Book> aRobertMartinBook = books.stream()
                .filter(book -> book.getAuthor().contains("Martin Fowler"))
                .findAny();

        assertThat(aRobertMartinBook.get().getAuthor(), is(equalTo("Martin Fowler")));
    }
[/vc_column_text][us_separator size=”small” show_line=”1″ icon=”fas|code”][vc_column_text]

orElse

An alternative to returning an optional from a findAny() call is to use orElse(….). This allows us to return a default value if there are no matches in the stream.

This example returns a Martin Fowler book if it exists in the collection or null if nothing is found:

    @Test
    void find_a_martin_fowler_book() {
        Book aMartinFowlerBook = books.stream()
                .filter(book -> book.getAuthor().contains("Martin Fowler"))
                .findAny()
                .orElse(null);

        assertThat(aMartinFowlerBook.getAuthor(), is(equalTo("Martin Fowler")));
    }
[/vc_column_text][us_separator size=”small” show_line=”1″ icon=”fas|code”][vc_column_text]

findFirst

The findFirst() method finds the first element in a Stream. Unlike findAny(…) it is deterministic.

This example finds the first Marting Fowler book in the stream or returns null:

    @Test
    void find_the_first_martin_fowler_book() {
        Book aMartinFowlerBook = books.stream()
                .filter(book -> book.getAuthor().contains("Martin Fowler"))
                .findFirst()
                .orElse(null);

        assertThat(aMartinFowlerBook.getTitle(), is(equalTo("Patterns of Enterprise Application Architecture")));
    }
[/vc_column_text][us_separator size=”small” show_line=”1″ icon=”fas|code”][vc_column_text]

orElseThrow

Similar to orElse but instead of returning a default value if nothing is found in the stream throw and exception.

This example looks a book written by codenerve and returns an exception if one does not exist:

    @Test
    void find_codenerves_awesome_book() {
        assertThrows(Exception.class, () ->
                books.stream()
                        .filter(book -> book.getAuthor().contains("Codenerve"))
                        .findFirst()
                        .orElseThrow(() -> new Exception("Codenerve hasn't written any good books yet :-(")));
    }
[/vc_column_text][/vc_tta_section][vc_tta_section icon=”fas|map” tab_id=”1593167228716-e014acf1-3e5d” title=”Map”][/vc_tta_section][/vc_tta_tour][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][vc_column_text]
